Poor oral hygiene status is considered to be a major risk factor for acquiring viral infections. Lack of manual dexterity and over‐dependency among older people hampers regular oral hygiene maintenance.
22 In a large cohort of older adults, the prevalence of dental caries among the dentate elderly was 22%, with 20% of the 75‐ to 84‐year‐olds presenting active root decay.
23 Accumulation of bacterial plaque with periodontally compromised teeth is the most frequent finding among the ageing adults.
24 When oral hygiene continues to remain poor, loss of teeth and edentulism occurs. Incidentally, tooth loss has been shown to have a positive relationship with mortality from all causes
25 and to the reduced quality of life impairment.
26 Geriatric patients with poor oral health are an independent in‐hospital mortality predictor.
